div.p: S. D. For a long time now, dearest Bullinger in the Lord, I have received no letters from our Haller; I believe the reason is that I have not yet settled in any fixed place where he could send letters. I am therefore informing him of where I am and what the state of my affairs is; I ask you to send the enclosed letters to him whenever the opportunity arises.

As for my wife's health, I still cannot predict where it will end. During the day, she seems to be better and gives hope of a quick recovery; but at night, she is almost consumed by fever, so much so that she sometimes struggles with a lapse of reason and mind. Two days ago, a fever also set in. The children, who were ill, are beginning to recover by the grace of the Lord, so that now I am uncertain only about my wife's health. I commend her, myself, and all my affairs to your prayers and those of your church. I know, I know the mercy of Christ the Savior, for whose eternal truth I have given myself to this exile, is so great and so certain that He will soon put an end to these troubles; in the meantime, however, it is both pious and necessary to use the prayers of the pious in the sight of God, which are always of great importance.
About Lord Leto, the chief grammarian of Augsburg, you may have already heard that he has been removed from the office he held by the new magistrate of Augsburg.
If you have anything about Frecht, please write. Farewell excellently; greetings to your most honorable wife, children, brothers, and friends.
Wolf[gang] Musculus, yours in the Lord.

Since Froschauer has rented out his house to others, in the meantime, I beseech you to look around for a place where I can stay with my family; for as soon as my wife either recovers or departs to the Lord, I will come to you, unless I am hindered by the will of the Lord.
To the most excellent theologian Lord Heinrich Bullinger, the most vigilant pastor of the church in Zürich, most esteemed lord and brother. Zürich.
